title: 103_hr671
content: The Act may be cited as the "Ted Weiss Memorial Health Care Fraud and Abuse Commission Act of 1993" and establishes the National Health Care Fraud and Abuse Commission. The "Ted Weiss Memorial Health Care Fraud and Abuse Commission" is established with 18 members including officials from various departments such as Health and Human Services, the Attorney General, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The "Ted Weiss Memorial Health Care Fraud and Abuse Commission" has 18 members including officials from Health and Human Services, the Attorney General, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Thirteen public members appointed by the President represent various sectors such as State medicaid fraud control programs, health insurance regulation, physicians, hospital administrators, health insurance companies, employers with self-funded health benefit plans. The President appoints representatives from various sectors to the "Ted Weiss Memorial Health Care Fraud and Abuse Commission," including employers with health benefit plans, medicare carriers, peer review organizations, health care consumers, medicare beneficiaries, and labor unions. Recommendations from national organizations representing these groups are considered in the appointment process. The President must report to Congress within 90 days after making appointments. The President appoints members to the Commission from various sectors, and must report their names to Congress within 90 days. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission's functions are outlined in Section 3. The Commission is tasked with investigating health care fraud and abuse in the US, developing effective prevention methods, and coordinating public and private efforts. They will examine mechanisms for standardizing claims administration and allowing health benefit plans to exchange information for fraud prevention without violating privacy protections. The Commission is exploring various aspects related to health care fraud and abuse, including extending administrative remedies to private insurers, organizing investigation efforts, creating model State statutes for insurance fraud units, regulating new healthcare providers, establishing criteria for physician referrals, and providing resources to combat fraud and abuse. The Commission is tasked with combating health care fraud and abuse. They will submit a report to Congress within 18 months of appointing public members, detailing their findings and recommendations. SEC. 4. ORGANIZATION AND COMPENSATION. The Commission shall have a majority quorum for hearings, elect a chairman from its members, and hold meetings as called by the chairman or majority. Meetings are open to the public, but can be in executive session with majority approval. Members serve without compensation but are reimbursed for expenses. Members of the Commission are reimbursed for expenses incurred in the performance of their duties. SEC. 5. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Commission may appoint staff and additional personnel without following standard appointment and compensation rules. Federal employees can be detailed to assist the Commission without losing their civil service status. The Commission can also hire temporary services at specific rates. The Commission has the authority to appoint staff and additional personnel without following standard rules. Federal employees can be detailed to assist the Commission without losing their civil service status. The Commission can also hire temporary services at specific rates, equivalent to 120 percent of the maximum annual rate of basic pay for GS-15 of the General Schedule. The Commission has the authority to appoint staff and additional personnel without following standard rules. Federal employees can be detailed to assist the Commission without losing their civil service status. The Commission can also hire temporary services at specific rates. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, obtain official data from government agencies, and make information available to the public as per the provisions of the Act. The Commission, under title 5, United States Code, can accept gifts, use the United States mails, receive administrative support services, and issue subpoenas for witness testimony and evidence. The Commission, under title 5, United States Code, can issue subpoenas for witness testimony and evidence related to investigations authorized under this Act. Witnesses can be required to attend hearings within the United States, and failure to obey a subpoena may result in a court order for testimony and evidence production, with non-compliance punishable as civil contempt. The court may punish non-compliance with subpoenas as civil contempt. Subpoenas are served as per Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Process serving can be done in the judicial district where the person resides. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting the report. Appropriations are authorized for the Commission's functions.
